Award.AwardTitle: Spokes: SMALL: SOUTH: Smart Privacy for Smart Cities: A Research Collaborative to Protect Privacy and Use Data Responsibly

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today's cities and communities, and their residents, are increasingly connected, and decisions are informed by actionable, real-time data. Data is making modern cities and local communities faster and safer, as well as more sustainable, livable, and equitable. At the same time, smart city technologies raise concerns about individuals' privacy, autonomy, choice, and possible misuse. Government officials are raising important questions about who should own data, how privacy protections for public-facing technologies work, who and how to communicate with the public about privacy, and more. The long-term vision of the project is to help municipal leaders strengthen their ability to collect, use, and share data in a responsible manner. This will help grow privacy-preserving innovations across applications and geographic boundaries for the public good. In this way, the Smart Privacy for Smart Cities Spoke will serve to increase public knowledge, understanding and engagement with privacy-related concerns, and ultimately promote the public's trust in smart city technologies and in their local government.

The Smart Privacy for Smart Cities Spoke is a collaborative project led by the FPF Education and Innovation Foundation (FPF EIF). It will undertake three interrelated activities to help city/community innovators understand and incorporate privacy considerations and protections into smart city projects. First, the Spoke will produce a privacy risk assessment framework for smart city projects, including guidance on what policies, practices and accountability structures should be put in place and how to weigh benefits of new or expanded data techniques against attendant privacy and security risks. The framework will feature a de-identification component as de-identification is one of the primary measures that organizations can take to protect and share data in a privacy-preserving manner. Second, the Spoke will establish a network of privacy leaders for smart cities and communities, helping municipal officials better understand, communicate, and collaboratively address privacy issues and principles. Lastly, the Spoke will hold two workshops in partnership with MetroLab Network, a national network of 40+ city-university partnerships advancing technological approaches to urban challenges. The workshops will serve to launch the privacy leaders network; educate network members about the privacy risk assessment framework; and identify areas for further collaboration and research, particularly in applying the framework to specific technologies and data uses. Expected project outcomes include wide dissemination of the privacy risk assessment framework and its adoption in specific localities; development of new collaborations and partnerships through the privacy leaders network and associated workshops; and as an overall outcome, the advancement of civic leaders' knowledge, understanding, and application of privacy protection(s) toward standards of practice for smart cities and privacy. The project will support and leverage the Hub Network, in particular the South Big Data Hub, NSF's Smart and Connected Communities program, and the MetroLab Network of city-university partners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the Big Data Spokes program, the Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) Education and Innovation Foundation launched and leads a Smart Privacy for Smart Cities Spoke, an active, authoritative source for public sector, academic, and industry researchers and managers to incorporate privacy considerations and assessments into smart city projects and develop widely acceptable principles, processes, and best practices. The project's goals are to help municipal leaders strengthen their ability to collect, use, and share data in a responsible manner by creating peer networks, best practices, and practical tools for civic data privacy; grow privacy-preserving innovations across application and geographic boundaries for the public good; and increase public knowledge, understanding, and engagement with privacy-related concerns, and ultimately promote the public's trust in smart and connected technologies and in local government. The project focused on three outcomes:

1) Launch of the Civic Data Privacy Leaders Network (CDPLN) to help local government actors better understand, communicate, and collaboratively address privacy issues and principles, as well as share best practices and tools. Formed in 2019, the network has grown to more than 90 municipal leaders representing over 30 counties and municipalities in the U.S. and Canada, and has attracted international attention from leaders in cities such as Brasilia, Sao Paolo, Barcelona, Dublin, Belfast, and London. The network began monthly calls in March 2019 structured to encourage open discussion and information sharing and to share experiences, questions, and lessons learned with peers to surface existing privacy best practices and to identify policy and practice gaps for future work. Members continue to meet on monthly calls to share information and contribute to a knowledge base on topics ranging from open data and public records acts, biometric data, AI and automated decision systems, access and use of mobility data, privacy program metrics and maturity models, COVID-19 response, and other timely data-related issues. FPF experts have provided direct consultation to members on their specific implementations and projects. In 2020, with the support of the City of Seattle, FPF launched a new Municipal Privacy Collaboration SharePoint site as an interactive, shared resource repository for the network's members, including resources about civic privacy practices, privacy impact assessments (PIAs), and privacy resources specific to COVID-19 response measures. See Smart Communities Resources for CDPLN localities and other project information.

2) Creation of a privacy risk assessment framework that can be adapted and applied to specific localities and technology implementations. FPF reviewed and synthesized PIA best practices from local, state, federal, and international entities and produced a draft "FPF Privacy Risk Assessment for Smart Cities and Communities" that incorporates issues beyond data protection, including ethics, equity, and public engagement. FPF socialized this privacy risk assessment framework and incorporated feedback from experts, including at CDPLN's monthly calls, at the 2019 MetroLab Network (MLN) Summit, and among FPF's other stakeholders. This risk assessment framework is a highlighted privacy resource for city and transportation leaders in the mobility space in the Open Mobility Foundation's "State of Practice" inventory and a featured resource in the NSF-supported U.S. Ignite program's Fostering Civic Trust: A Policy Guide for Municipal Leaders. In 2020, FPF published a "Model PIA Policy for Smart Cities" as part of the G20 Smart Cities Alliance, which substantially incorporates and builds on this risk assessment framework, providing an "off-the-shelf" policy framework for conducting PIAs as part of smart city initiatives that is designed to accelerate and enable the implementation of PIAs worldwide.

3) Production of workshops in collaboration with MetroLab Network (MLN) to educate its partners in universities and cities on privacy strategies and requirements and drive discussion around specific technologies or data uses/practices. Building on earlier start-up activities with MLN, the new CDPLN met at the 2019 MLN Annual Summit and the fall 2020 MLN Summit Series. Additional workshops and events were organized on trust in the public realm, smart city wireless technology development, and privacy and responsible data use for pandemic response. In 2020, FPF hosted a special roundtable at the MLN Annual Summit dedicated to "Building a Civic/Municipal Privacy Resource Library" where CDPLN and MLN participants brainstormed about how to identify, curate, and publish privacy resources for municipal leaders, partners, and community members. Through these and similar workshops, the Spoke attracts new participants, validates emerging best practices, strengthens city-academic partnerships, and identifies areas for further collaboration and research.

Building off its work under the BD Spokes program, the CDPLN seeks to remain an active network to promote the interaction of industry and academic researchers with municipal privacy officials and to develop resources and privacy-preserving tools for their communities. FPF and CDPLN are exploring mechanisms to support the network as a continued important and timely resource for NSF-supported academic and other researchers working on development of new concepts and technologies in the smart city space with direct access to municipal privacy officials and industry.
